column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Books

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Implementing the Common Core State Standards through Mathematical Problem Solving, Grades 35

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Mary Q. Foot, Darrell Earnest, and Shiuli Mukhopadhyay, 2014.   Foreword by Frances Curcio, series ed. 123 pp., $26.95 paper. ISBN 9780873537247. Stock no. 14446. National Council of Teachers of Mathematics; www.nctm.org.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The thirty-eight tasks contained in Implementing the Common Core State Standards through Mathematical Problem Solving 35 are a treasure for teachers to add to their collection of problem-solving activities. Because of the across-grade-level perspective of the book, its usefulness is not restricted to simply teachers of third, fourth, and fifth grades. A three-part lesson format encourages teachers to consider a variety of ways to launch a task, anticipates both correct and incorrect student responses during task exploration, and includes summarizing discussions as a non-negotiable norm when it comes to a problem-solving lesson (p. 3).

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Task 2.5: Interpreting Remainders offers three meaningful examples highlighting three completely different situations when encountering remainder problems that students often misunderstand. The ideas for launching, exploring, and summarizing the task were clearly written and relevant. I appreciate the approach to contextualizing the problems as well as the quality of questions offered for conducting the discussion. The useful qualities of this task are repeated throughout the book when addressing such topics as developing understanding of multiplying and dividing fractions as well as measurement and conversion.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Implementing the Common Core State Standards through Mathematical Problem Solving 35 addresses all the areas that classroom teachers are looking for and contains tasks that teachers could immediately take off the page and into the classroom. This is one of those resources that teachers will reach for again and again. They should have a well-worn book at the end of the school year.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Insights into Mathematical Thought: Excursions with Distributivity

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Stephen I. Brown, 2013. 111 pp., $26.95 paper. ISBN 978-0-87353-712 4. Stock no. 14338. National Council of Teachers of Mathematics; www.nctm.org.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Generally speaking, this book tackles a nice range of mathematical topics in an approachable way. Using illustrative geometric representations coupled with accessible algebraic manipulations, the   author develops unique, sometimes playful, explanations for the topics, while holding to an understandable level of rigor.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Throughout the explanations, the author invites readers to consider interesting perspectives about mathematical relationships, explore parallel ideas and relationships, or deepen awareness about the ideas by investigating them further. As suggested by the title, the distributive property is used to connect several seemingly unrelated notions or to provide alternative explanations for familiar concepts.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: However, this book journeys beyond distributivity by elaborating on topics like the Pythagorean theorem from Euclids point of view to items such as isomorphisms and imaginary numbers of more recent times. Different chapters will more or less resonate with readers according to their correspondingly different levels of mathematical sophistication and prior experiences. However, the book is written to attract a broad audience and to accommodate readers who wish to pick their own pathways through the chapters.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: To gain the intended insights from these essays, in whatever manner is chosen to sequence topics, readers will become involved in making meaning of the mathematics, working collaboratively with the author to solve problems and prove conjectures.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: This book is recommended for readers who want to move beyond being passive observers of mathematics to actively exploring ideas that will ultimately lead to insights into mathematical thought.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Janet Sharp

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Washburn University

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Topeka, Kansas

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Math Is a Verb: Activities and Lessons from Cultures around the World

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Jim Barta, Ron Eglash, and Cathy Barkley, 2014. 163 pp., $29.85 paper. ISBN 978-0-87353-07-0.   Stock no. 14326. National Council  of Teachers of Mathematics;   www.nctm.org.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: This book is a resource for teachers looking to integrate culturally diverse understandings of mathematics in their classrooms. As the authors discuss in their introduction, culturally responsive mathematics teaching helps students see mathematics as more than just a subject learned in school, isolated from their daily lives and home cultures.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The eleven chapters in the book each present an activity, object, or game specific to the culture being explored. Chapters begin by placing the featured activity in a historical or cultural context that emphasizes the connections between the mathematics as a problem-solving activity and the cultures values. For example, the chapter on Graffiti Shapes and Styles links early cave paintings or Roman soldiers carving their names in the Colosseum to a basic human desire to leave a physical reminder of ones existence in a certain time and place. Other chapters that discuss gambling and games of chance point out that these activities have been part of human cultures worldwide throughout history.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Activities are organized by grade bands (K3, 48, 912) and are aligned with both the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics and NCTM Standards. Many of the activities are nonroutine applications of middle school work with transformational geometry and probability.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The mathematics and activities in this book are not out of the box.  They require teachers to familiarize themselves with new applications of the mathematics they know and teach. Many of the lessons use applications on the Culturally Situated Design Tools (CSDT) website. Teachers will need to become familiar with the design tools and develop lesson plans that are specific to their grade level. The book would have benefited from an index of activities by standard to assist teachers who were looking to supplement their curriculum.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Note: The book comes with a code to access the More4U website through NCTM with lesson plans, bonus activities, and links to the Culturally Situated Design Tools website.

column3: Kathy Rubendall

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: FROM OTHER PUBLISHERS

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Pirate Math: Developing   Mathematical Reasoning   with Games and Puzzles

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Michael Serra, 2014. 275 pp.,   $32.95 paper. ISBN 9780  983409915. Playing it Smart; www.michaelserra.net.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Michael Serras newest venture into game-based recreational mathematics, Pirate Math: Developing Mathematical Reasoning with Games and Puzzles is a highly engaging followup to Smart Moves (2012), which incorporated foundational math principles with an overarching theme to keep secondary students, as well as teachers, playing and working.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Within the context of discovering buried treasure, Serra guides the user through such topics as Cartesian coordinate systems (in two and three dimensions), linear equations, geometry, and cryptography while providing a groundwork for using polyominoes, for which credit is given to its creator, Solomon Golumb.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Through a framework of tutorials, clear instructions, and engaging pirate-themed games, students develop a clear, practical understanding of key mathematics concepts while participating in fun math activities. The user can adjust the level of kitsch, according to taste.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The appendixes provide a wealth of references to the text, with sections devoted to a review of linear equations, model building, activity hints, and answer keys as well as a section of reproducible game sheets (including a note from the author that no part of the work can be reproduced without permission of the publisher, via email).

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Overall, Serras Pirate Math succeeds in pulling together well-  explained mathematics content, structured activity, and a great theme to engage students from a wide audience. In his forty-plus years in education, he has learned how to convey content in a way that students can internalize and apply as their math career progresses.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Tim Kubinak

column3: Fellow, Siemens STEM Institute

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: STEM Integration in K12   Education: Status, Prospects,   and an Agenda for Research

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Margaret Honey, Greg Pearson, and Heidi Schweingruber, eds., 2014. 180 pp., $47.00 paper. ISBN 9780309297967. The National Academies Press; www.nap.edu.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: In this book, the committee on   Integrated STEM Education,   comprising members from the National Academy of Engineering and the National Research Council, report the research from a two-year study. The authors detail the research process and provide a summary for current instructional practices used in STEM integration. Audiences for the book are Kgrade 12 stakeholders, curriculum designers, assessment developers, and researchers. Although STEM integration is currently used in educational settings, the research committee found little documented evidence that current efforts are achieving the desired outcomes in all content areas.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Chapters 2 and 3 discuss the research framework and review the literature for a positive influence of integration of STEM concepts. The descriptive framework includes goals, outcomes, nature of integration, and implementation. Research goals for students are STEM literacy, twenty-firstcentury competencies, STEM workforce readiness, interest and engagement, and ability to make connections among STEM disciplines. Educators have the separate goals of increasing content knowledge and pedagogical strategies.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Teachers, curriculum designers, and assessment creators will find chapters 4 and 5 a resource for integrating STEM courses for achievement and outcomes with learning, cognition, and contextual knowledge. STEM courses deepen the understanding for students so they can make connections across disciplines. Strategies are discussed for teaching strategies and designing assessment for STEM integration.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The resource contains findings and recommendations for further research. I would recommend the book for anyone who is interested in research or designing assessments as well as for teachers of STEM disciplines. Finally, the book could assist professional development ideas with topics from the research committees recommendations.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Vickie Breauchy

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Palmetto Scholars Academy

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: North Charleston, South Carolina

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Uncomplicating Algebra to   Meet Common Core Standards   in Math, K8

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Marian Small, 2014. 176 pp., $27.95 paper. ISBN 978-0-8077- 5517-4. Teachers College Press; www.tcpress.com.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: A challenge facing every Kgrade 8 teacher and coach is making sense of how the Common Core State Standards for School Mathematics build across grades to support the development of fluent, proficient doers of mathematics. Uncomplicating Algebra supports teachers in making sense of this landscape, with respect to algebra and algebraic thinking.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Each chapter focuses on one grade, Kgrade 8, and is organized by themes.  Examples of themes include Using Equations to Describe Addition and Subtraction, (K); Arithmetic Generalizations, (grade 4); and Solving Measurement Problems with Equations, (grade 7).  The language used for the themes helps paint the big picture of what might be done at the grade level to support algebraic thinking and skills.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Each theme is followed by a list of the relevant grade-level standards, grouped by domain, and Important Underlying Ideas, which attends to conceptual underpinnings, connections to grade-level content, and common misconceptions. For example, for Using Equations to Describe Addition and Subtraction, (K), the author discusses equations describing a balance and equations describing a relationship. Although the research is not cited, it is clear that the underlying ideas discussed are grounded in the research base.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The final component, Good Questions to Ask, is a real strength of each chapter. It offers specific questions, with answers, that support students engagement with the Important Underlying Ideas and standards. The prompts are thoughtful and practical, providing immediate guidance for implementing and envisioning algebraic thinking in a classroom.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Overall, I recommend this book. It is useful for framing the work within and across Kgrade 8 needed to   develop algebraic thinkers.

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: Megan Staples

column2: Book, Product, and Software Reviews (February 2015) - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: University of Connecticut
